__data__.text: Introduction After the publication of the Basel IV standard on December 2017, the BCBS published a consolidated Basel Framework on April 2019 which adjusted the previous Basel IV standard with small editorial changes to simplify, clarify or reorganize the different publications into a single framework. This updated version of the Basel IV text was the basis of this requirements document. The requirements that are embedded in the formal proposal of the CRR III are based on the regulations stated in the BCBS publication of April 2019 (hereafter Basel IV).1   The European Committee disclosed the formal proposal of the CRR III and CRD VI, including the Basel IV implementation in European law in October 2021. In this proposal some differences compared to Basel IV are introduced. Therefore, this document will reference the CRR III articles together with the Basel IV Requirements. When Basel IV and CRR III differ, CRR III is leading. Under CRR III there are two broad methodologies for calculating their risk-based capital requirements for credit risk. The first, the Standardised Approach (SA), assigns standardised risk weights to exposures. The second approach, which is subject to supervisory approval, is the Internal Ratings-Based (IRB) in which the risk weights are calculated based on (internal) estimates of PD, LGD and EAD. Even when the IRB approach is used, the SA risk weights need to be calculated and used in the output floor that applies to all exposures. This document condenses the requirements set in the draft Capital Requirements Regulations (CRR) III applicable to retail exposures under the standardised approach to a document usable for its implementation.   1.1. Governance Bank X has a review and approval process governance in place for the development of models. Since the regulatory requirements for Basel IV are not considered a model2, this process is not applicable. In order to guarantee sufficient reviews and involvement of the most relevant stakeholders the Basel IV requirement team Credit Risk designed a Basel IV specific governance process for the requirement packages.      1Basel IV is an international regulatory framework for banks, developed by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS). 2 Decision

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: 1.2. Definitions General key definitions are described in relevant regulations (CRR and Basel IV) and by Bank X.  Credit exposure Credit exposure is defined in the Global Standard CRP3; there is no impact of the new CRR III Article 5 (5) definition.4 Credit exposure means that a claim results or could result from a legally binding credit agreement. This agreement means a contract or otherwise written agreement under which Bank X (as part of ordinary banking operations) has a claim or could obtain a claim on an Obligor by providing any product or service. This includes but is not limited to loans, overdraft Facilities, derivatives, bank guarantees, letters of credit and treasury services. This could result in on-balance or off-balance exposure.5  Facility Facility is defined in the Global Standard CRP6; there is no impact of the new CRR III Article 5 (6) definition.7  All or part of an exposure resulting from a Legally Binding Credit Agreement and consisting of a unique (i) set of terms and conditions and/or (ii) account/transaction number. This includes both on- and off-balance exposures resulting from such an agreement.  Obligor  3 ‘GS CRP or Global Standard Credit Risk Parameters version 2.0 at the time of writing 4 CRR III Article 5(5): ‘credit exposure’ means any on-balance sheet item, including any amount of  principal, accrued interest and fees owed by the obligor to the institution, and any off-balance sheet item that results, or may result, in a credit obligation. 5 The different options for determining the exposure amount is explained in the Credit Risk Mitigation document.  The exposure amount is calculated in the following manner: OnbalanceAmount (as defined in footnote 6) + (OffbalanceAmount * CCF), where CCF is based on the values as prescribed by the standardised approach. The exposure amount on obligor/joint obligor level is determined by taking the sum of all exposures belonging to this counterparty or one-obligor. 6 ‘GS CRP or Global Standard Credit Risk Parameters version 2.0 at the time of writing 7 CRR III Article 5(6): ‘facility’ means a credit exposure arising from contract or a set of contracts between an obligor and an institution.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Obligor is defined in the Global Standard CRP; there is no impact of the CRR III legislation on this definition. An Obligor can consist of an Individual Obligor, or a Joint Obligor, meaning one or more: Counterparties (bond issuer, borrower, debtor, co-debtor, co-borrower, etc.) who have (solely or jointly) entered in one or more Legally Binding Credit Agreements with Bank X and therefore: (i) has contractual obligation to make payments related to any underlying Facility and (ii) should act in accordance with the terms of the agreement.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Institution An ‘institution’ means a credit institution authorised under Article 8 of Directive 2013/36/EU or an undertaking as referred to in Article 8a(3) of this Directive (CRR III Article 4(3)).  Credit Institution A ‘credit institution’ means an undertaking the business of which consists of any of the following (CRR III Article 4(1)): a) to take deposits or other repayable funds from the public and to grant credits for its own account; b) to carry out any of the activities referred to in points (3) and (6) of Section A of Annex I (Directive 2014/65/EU Article 8a8) of the European Parliament and of the Council, where one of the following applies, but the undertaking is not a commodity and emission allowance dealer, a collective investment undertaking or an insurance undertaking: • the total value of the consolidated assets of the undertaking is equal to or exceeds EUR 30 billion; • the total value of the assets of the undertaking is less than EUR 30 billion, and the undertaking is part of a group in which the total value of the consolidated assets of all undertakings in that group that individually have total assets of less than EUR 30 billion and that carry out any of the activities referred to in points (3) and (6) of Section A of Annex I to Directive 2014/65/EU is equal to or exceeds EUR 30 billion; • the total value of the assets of the undertaking is less than EUR 30 billion, and the undertaking is part of a group in which the total value of the consolidated assets of all undertakings in the group that carry out any of the activities referred to in points (3) and (6) of Section A of Annex I to Directive 2014/65/EU is equal to or exceeds EUR 30 billion, where the consolidating supervisor, in consultation with the supervisory college, so decides in order to address potential risks of circumvention and potential risks for the financial stability of the Union;  For the purposes bullets two and three in b), where the undertaking is part of a third‐country group, the total assets of each branch of the third‐country group authorised in the Union shall be included in the combined total value of the assets of all undertakings in the group.     8 This article gives specific requirements for the authorisation of credit institutions.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Financial institutions A new definition in CRR III is the definition for a financial institution. A ‘financial institution’ means an undertaking that meets both of the following conditions (CRR III Article 4(26)):  a) the undertaking is not an institution, a pure industrial holding company, an insurance holding company or a mixed‐activity insurance holding company as defined in Article 212(1), points (f) and (g), of Directive 2009/138/EC;  b) the undertaking fulfils one of the following conditions: • the principal activity of the undertaking is to acquire or own holdings or to pursue one or more of the activities listed Annex I, points 2 to 12 and point 15, to Directive 2013/36/EU, or to pursue one or more of the services or activities listed in Annex I, Section 1 or B, to Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council53 in relation to financial instruments listed in Section C of that Annex to that Directive; • the undertaking is an investment firm, a mixed financial holding company, an investment holding company, a payment services provider within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2015/2366 of the European Parliament and of the Council54, an asset management company or an ancillary services undertaking.  Investment firm An ‘investment firm’ means an investment firm as defined in point (1) of Article 4(1) of Directive 2014/65/EU which is authorised under that Directive but excludes credit institutions.

Acronyms and abbreviations Abbreviation Description AIRB Advanced Internal Rating Based  CCF Credit Conversion Factor DNB De Nederlandsche Bank EA Exposure Amount = on balance exposure + (off-balance exposure x CCF) ECRA External Credit Risk Assessment Approach EID  Exposure In Default (for non-performing facilities) LGD  Loss Given Default OFBS  Off-balance Sheet OBSI  On balance Sheet Item PD Probability of Default RWA Risk Weighted Assets RW Risk Weight SCRA Standardised Credit Risk Assessment Approach SA Standardised Approach TRBE Trade Related Bank Exposure

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: General requirements  2.1. Introduction This section details the general and Institutions specific requirements as stated in Basel IV for the calculation of RWA under the standardised approach. The general requirements stated in the paragraphs CRE20.4 to CRE20.6 of Basel IV are consistent with the existing general requirements stated in the Committee’s guidance on the assessment of credit risk and with the paragraphs 733 to 735 of the Basel II framework. These general requirements stated from Basel IV, which are fully cited in appendix Error! Reference source not found., can be summarised as follows: • Banks must perform due diligence of the risk profile and characteristics of their counterparties on regular basis; • Banks must be able to access information about their counterparties on a regular basis to complete due diligence analyses; • Banks should have in place effective internal policies, processes, systems and controls to ensure that the appropriate risk weights are assigned to counterparties; • Banks must be able to demonstrate to their supervisors that their due diligence analyses are appropriate; • National supervisors should ensure that banks put in place underwriting policies with respect to the granting of mortgage loans that include the assessment of the ability of the borrower to repay. These requirements are not part of the draft CRR III and therefore placed out of scope of this document.  Comment The section above describes the required Customer Due Diligence according to Basel IV. However, these kind of due diligence rules are not stated in the CRR text, but in other regulations that affect banks. For this reason Bank X has written a Global Standard on Customer Due Diligence.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: 2.2. Classification of institutions This document covers the exposures to institutions, i.e. rated institutions and unrated institutions according to CRR III Articles 119, 120, 121. Exposures to institutions for which a credit assessment by a nominated ECAI is available shall be risk-weighted in accordance with Article 120. Exposures to institutions for which a credit assessment by a nominated ECAI is not available shall be risk-weighted in accordance with Article 121 (CRR III Article 119(1)). The treatment of the exposures to institutions is set out in Section 2.3. As stated in Section 1.2, the CRR III definition states that an institution is an entity which takes deposits or other repayable funds from the public and grants credits for its own account or an investment firm which provides only one or more of the investment services and activities listed in points 1, 2, 4 and 5 of Section A of Annex I to Directive 2014/65/EU. Interpretation Bank X is currently using NAICS codes to distinguish institutions. NAICS code are assigned according to the main activity of a company. Therefore the continued use of NAICS codes is proposed, see appendix Error! Reference source not found. for the specific NAICS codes.   NAICS are currently already used within Bank X and a project is ongoing to improve the quality of the NAICS code in the system. Because of the fact that the NAICS codes of counterparty in the Bank X system are not 100% reliable at this moment assessment of the counterparty in the annual review should be included to determine if the counterparty is correctly classified. In addition, as part of the annual credit review cycle, an assessment has to take place to check if a licence is in place. If this is the case, the institution can be classified as a bank.   Just like was the case in CRR II, and already stated in Section 1.6, exposures to financial institutions authorised and supervised by the competent authorities and subject to prudential requirements comparable to those applied to institutions in terms of robustness shall be treated as exposures to institutions (CRR III Article 119(5)).

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Exposures to investment firms and other financial institutions can be treated either as corporate exposures or as exposures to institutions. Exposures to investment firms and other financial institutions will be treated as exposures to institutions provided that these firms are subject to prudential standards and a level of supervision equivalent to those applied to institutions (including capital and liquidity requirements). National supervisors should determine whether the regulatory and supervisory framework governing investment firms and other financial institutions in their own jurisdictions is equivalent to that which is applied to institutions in their own jurisdictions. Exposures to all other investment firms and financial institutions will be treated as exposures to corporates. Interpretation For a financial institution to be treated as an institution it should be authorised like an institution, as stated in CRR III Article 119(5).9 In addition, appropriate supervision is required. Financial institutions under CRR supervision fulfil the criteria of appropriate prudential standards set by CRR and for financial institutions outside the Union, appendix 3.510 shows which countries have prudential regulation that is deemed equivalent. Only if the prudential regulation is deemed equivalent a counterparty can be treated as an institution.    CRR article 107(3) states that, for the purposes of this Regulation, exposures to third country investment firms, exposures to third country credit institutions and exposures to third country clearing houses and exchanges, as well as exposures to third country financial institutions authorised and supervised by third country authorities and subject to prudential requirements comparable to those applied to institutions in terms of robustness,  shall be treated as exposures to an institution only if the third country applies prudential and supervisory requirements to that entity that are at least equivalent to those applied in the Union. Although this article was already present in the previous CRR, the part about financial institutions was added in CRR III.     9 As stated in the Section 1.6, the authorisation of an institution is specified in CRD Article 8(a). 10 The countries which are mentioned in this appendix are brought up from points 19 and 20 of the following European Regulations.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: 2.3. Treatment of exposures to institutions Exposure to an institution in the form of minimum reserves required by the ECB or by the central bank of a Member State to be held by an institution may be risk-weighted as exposures to the central bank of the Member State in question provided that (CRR III Article 119(4)): (a) the reserves are held in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1745/2003 of the European Central Bank of 12 September 2003 on the application of minimum reserves or in accordance with national requirements in all material respects equivalent to that Regulation; (b) in the event of the bankruptcy or insolvency of the institution where the reserves are held, the reserves are fully repaid to the institution in a timely manner and are not made available to meet other liabilities of the institution. Interpretation This article was already there in CRR II and it states that if we have exposures to the central bank via an intermediary, and this exposure represents minimum reserves required by ECB or another Central Bank, then we can use the risk weight of an ECB or Central Bank exposure instead of the risk weight of the intermediary. The DNB states the following about this: “In appropriate cases, institutions are offered the possibility to hold their minimum reserve indirectly via an intermediary. For more information about the possibilities with respect to indirect holding of reserves, […]”  Interpretation Bank X currently includes insurance companies in the FI exposures class whereas they should be classified as corporate under CRR. This is because insurance companies do not fulfil the definition of financial institutions given by CRR. They do not perform activities listed in annex I of the CRD, see Appendix Error! Reference source not found., points 1/ tm 12 or 15. See also EBA Q&A 2013- 383 where is stated that insurance companies are not a financial institution. The Q&A states: “Insurance undertakings, reinsurance undertakings, insurance holding companies and mixed-activity insurance holding companies are not considered as financial institutions pursuant to the definition in point 26 of Article 4(1) of the CRR.”

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: All other exposures of institutions will be risk-weighted in one of the following ways (CRR Article 119(1)):11 1. Exposures to rated institutions (CRR III Article 120): This approach is for institutions incorporated in jurisdictions that allow the use of external ratings for regulatory purposes. It applies to all their rated exposures to institutions. Since Bank X belongs to a jurisdiction where the use of external ratings is allowed, this approach has to be used. Bank X experts estimated that 50% of the Institutions portfolio has an external rating. Where institutions are commonly rated this is not the case for smaller institutions counterparties. See Section 0 for an in depth explanation of the exposures to rated institutions.  2. Exposures to unrated institutions (CRR III Article 121): This approach applies to exposures to institutions that are unrated in jurisdictions that allow the use of external ratings for regulatory purposes. This is applicable to Bank X. The other intent of the SCRA is to risk weight all exposures of institutions incorporated in jurisdictions that do not allow the use of external ratings for regulatory purposes. See Section 2.3.2 for an in depth explanation of the exposures to unrated institutions.  2.3.1. Exposures to rated institutions The table below shows the risk weights to be used for institutions based on applicable external ratings. In general the base risk weight has to be used (CRR III Article 120(1)), but for short-term (with original maturity of three months or less) exposures, or for those arising from the movement of goods across national borders with an original maturity of six months or less, reduced risk weights can be used (CRR III Article 120(2)). A more extensive explanation about exposures to rated institutions can be found in the External Ratings document.  Table 2: Overview of risk weights for institutions that are allowed to use external ratings (ECAIs) (table 3 and 4 in CRR III Article 120 (1&2))  11 With the exception of exposures giving rise to Common Equity Tier 1. Additional Tier 1 and Tier 2 items, national supervisors may allow banks belonging to the same institutional protection scheme (such as mutual, cooperatives or savings institutions) in their jurisdictions to apply a lower risk weight than that indicated by the ECRA and SCRA to their intra-group or in-network exposures provided that both counterparties to the exposures are members of the same effective institutional protection scheme that is a contractual or statutory arrangement set up to protect those institutions and seeks to ensure their liquidity and solvency to avoid bankruptcy. If this is allowed the institution, may assign a risk weight of 0%. See also CRR article 113.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: External Credit Risk Assessment Approach Credit Quality Step 1 2 3 4 5 6 Unrated “Base” risk weight 20% 30% 50% 100% 100% 150% SCRA Risk weight for short-term exposures 20% 20% 20% 50% 50% 150% SCRA  2.3.2. Exposures to unrated institutions The approach for exposures to unrated institutions also applies to unrated exposures for institutions incorporated in jurisdictions that allow the use of external ratings for regulatory purposes. However, the primary scope of application of this approach is for institutions incorporated in jurisdictions that do not allow the use of external ratings to risk weight their exposures to all their institution exposures.  This approach requires banks to classify institution exposures into one of three risk-weight buckets (i.e. Grades A, B and C)12 and makes a distinction between a base risk weight and a risk weight for short-term exposures see table 3.  Table 3: Overview of risk weights for unrated exposures to institutions (SCRAs) (table 5 in CRR III (Article 121(2))   Standardised Credit Risk Assessment Approach Credit risk assessment of Counterparty Grade A*  Grade A Grade B Grade C “Base” risk weight 30% 40% 75% 150% Risk weight for short-term exposures 20% 20% 50% 75%   12 This is a new calculation method for the Standardised Credit Risk Assessment Approach in CRR III compared to CRR II. This new calculation was, however, already implemented in Basel IV.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Exposures assigned to one of the risk-weight buckets which meet one of the following conditions shall be assigned a risk weight for short-term exposures in accordance with table 3 above, second column (CRR III Article 121(2a)): (i) the exposure has an original maturity of three months or less;  (ii) the exposure has an original maturity of six months or less and arises from the movement of goods across national borders. Interpretation Grade A* was added as it has the same requirements as Grade A plus some extra requirements explained below. The risk weights are even lower than Grade A, hence A*. CRR III does not use this terminology, however the risk weight is mentioned in CRR III Article 121(2b).  2.3.2.1. Grade A* Grade A* refers to unrated exposures that are assigned to Grade A where all of the following conditions are met (CRR III Article 121(2b)): (i) the institution’s Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio is equal to or higher than 14%; (ii) the institution’s leverage ratio is higher than 5%.  2.3.2.2. Grade A  Where all of the following conditions are met, exposures to institutions shall be assigned to Grade A (CRR III Article 121(1)): (i) the institution has adequate capacity to meet their financial commitments (including repayments of principal and interest) in a timely manner, for the projected life of the assets or exposures and irrespective of the economic cycles and business conditions; (ii) the institution meets or exceeds the requirement laid down in Article 92(1), the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104a of Directive 2013/36/EU, the combined buffer requirement defined in Article 128, point (6), of Directive 2013/36/EU and any equivalent or additional local supervisory or regulatory requirements in third countries, as those requirements are published and are to be met by Common Equity Tier 1 capital, Tier 1 capital or own funds;

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: (iii) information about the requirements referred to in point (ii) is publicly disclosed or otherwise made available; (iv) the assessment in accordance with Article 79 of Directive 2013/36/EU has not revealed that the institution does not meet the conditions set out in points (i) and (ii). For points (i) and (ii) interpretation boxes have been written which can be found on the next two pages.   Interpretation To classify the counterparty in grade A. the counterparty has to have adequate capacity to meet their financial commitments. This should be determined by due diligence on the counterparty. As part of the due diligence the RRR can be used as a proxy. Grade A would be R10 or better on the RRR internal Bank X score, this is irrespective of the PD model used. The description corresponding to R10 is deemed most equivalent to the description of grade A. The due diligence should be performed at least on an annual basis and should be covered by the regular credit review cycle. Amongst other thing the internal RRR score can be used as an proxy during the due diligence. If the RRR score deviates a lot from the external rating in a negative way, the risk weight coming from the external rating should be adjusted. However, if no RRR is available the due diligence still needs to be performed. In that case the exposure will have Grade C (see section 2.3.2.4).  The masterscale description of R10 is : “ADEQUATE capacity to meet financial commitments. However, major adverse economic conditions or changing sector/business specific circumstances could lead to a weakened capacity to meet financial commitments”.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Interpretation In order for a counterparty to be classified as grade A or A*, the minimum regulatory requirements and buffers should be met and published:  Institutions must meet the following requirements coming at all times (CRR III Article 92(1)): (1) Common Equity Tier 1 must be at least 4.5% of risk-weighted assets (RWA). (2) Tier 1 capital must be at least 6% of RWA. (3) Total capital must be at least 8.0% of RWA. (4) A leverage ratio of 3% was added to article 92 by CRR II.  Besides the capital conservation buffer stated in CRD Article 129 should be met, in combination met following buffers (CRD article 128(6)): a) an institution-specific countercyclical capital buffer;  b) a G-SII buffer; c) an O-SII buffer; d) a systemic risk buffer,   The new EBA recommendations also stated that where binding minimum own funds requirements under Pillar II exist in the jurisdiction of the counterparty institution, these should also be taken into account. For counterparties in third countries the corresponding national minimum requirements are applicable. For exposures to third-country institutions Article 107(3) of CRR applies and hence only if the supervision in that country is deemed equivalent the counterparty will be treated as an institution. If  third-country supervision is not deemed equivalent the counterparty should be treated as corporate.  The counterparty should make these requirements publicly available or available to Bank X to be considered for grade A or A*. If these are not made available by the counterparty institution the counterparty must be assessed as grade B or lower.  If one of these conditions is not fulfilled the financial institution must be assessed as Grade B or below.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: 2.3.2.3. Grade B Where all of the following conditions are met and at least one of the conditions for Grade A, stated in Section 2.3.2.2, is not met, exposures to institutions shall be assigned to Grade B (CRR III Article 121(b)):  (i) the institution is subject to substantial credit risk, including repayment capacities that are dependent on stable or favourable economic or business conditions; (ii) the institution meets or exceeds the requirement laid down in Article 92(1), the requirements referred to in Articles 458 and 459, the specific own funds requirements referred to in Article 104a of Directive 2013/36/EU and any equivalent or additional local supervisory or regulatory requirements insofar as those requirements are published and are to be met by Common Equity Tier 1 capital, Tier 1 capital and own funds; (iii) information about the requirements referred to in point (ii) is publicly disclosed or otherwise made available; (iv) the assessment performed in accordance with Article 79 of Directive 2013/36/EU has not revealed that the institution does not meet the conditions set out in points (i) and (ii). For points (i) and (ii) interpretation boxes have been written which can be found on the next two pages.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Interpretation To classify the counterparty in Grade B the counterparty has to have adequate capacity to meet their financial commitments. This should be determined by due diligence on the counterparty. As part of the due diligence the RRR can be used as a proxy. Grade B would be R14 or better on the RRR internal Bank X score, this is irrespective of the PD model used. The description corresponding to R14 is deemed most equivalent to the description of grade B. The due diligence should be performed at least on an annual basis and should be covered by the regular credit review cycle. Amongst other thing the internal RRR score can be used as an proxy during the due diligence. If the RRR score deviates a lot from the external rating in a negative way, the risk weight coming from the external rating should be adjusted. However if no RRR is available the due diligence still needs to be performed. In that case the exposure will have Grade C (see section 2.3.2.4).  The masterscale description of R14 is the following: “SATISFACTORY capacity to meet financial commitments. However, major adverse economic conditions or changing sector/business specific circumstances could lead to inadequate capacity to meet financial commitments.”   For the purposes of point (ii), equivalent or additional local supervisory or regulatory requirements shall not include capital buffers equivalent to those defined in Article 128 of Directive 2013/36/EU. If one of these conditions is not fulfilled the financial institution must be assessed as Grade C.

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text: Interpretation The published minimum regulatory requirements and buffers that should be met for a counterparty to be classified as grade B are the following: Institutions must meet the following requirements at all times (CRR III Article 92(1)): (1) Common Equity Tier 1 must be at least 4.5% of risk-weighted assets (RWA). (2) Tier 1 capital must be at least 6% of RWA. (3) Total capital must be at least 8.0% of RWA. (4) A leverage ratio of 3% was added to article 92 by CRR II. The new EBA recommendations also stated that where binding minimum own funds requirements under Pillar II exist in the jurisdiction of the counterparty institution, these should also be taken into account.  For counterparties in third countries the corresponding national minimum requirements are applicable. For exposures to third-country institutions Article 107(3) of CRR applies and hence only if the supervision in that country is deemed equivalent the counterparty will be treated as an institution. If third-country supervision is not deemed equivalent the counterparty should be treated as corporate.  The counterparty should make these requirements publicly available or available to Bank X to be considered for grade B. If these are not made available by the counterparty institution, the counterparty must be assessed as grade C.  2.3.2.4. Grade C If the conditions for assignment to Grade A or Grade B are not met, or if any of the following conditions is met, exposures to institutions shall be assigned to Grade C (CRR III Article 121(c)):  (i) the institution has material default risks and limited margins of safety; (ii) adverse business, financial, or economic conditions are very likely to lead, or have led, to the institution’s inability to meet its financial commitments; (iii) where audited financial statements are required by law for the institution, the external auditor has issued an adverse audit opinion or has expressed substantial

metadata.file_name: Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf
Bank X- SA Institutions Regulatory Requirements.pdf

__data__.text:
doubt in its financial statements or audited reports within the previous 12 months about the institution’s ability to continue as a going concern institution.  Where an exposure to an institution is not denominated in the domestic currency of the jurisdiction of incorporation of that institution, the risk weight assigned in accordance with table 3 to exposures other than those with a maturity of one year or less stemming from self-liquidating, trade-related contingent items that arise from the movement of goods across national borders shall not be lower than the risk weight of an exposure to the central government of the country where the institution is incorporated. This also applies when that institution has booked the credit obligation in a branch in a different jurisdiction and the exposure is not in the domestic currency of the jurisdiction in which the branch operates.  
  Interpretation  The country where the relevant counterparty is incorporated is the country where the counterparty is formed to a corporate entity or company. A corporation is the resulting legal entity from incorporation that separates the firm's assets and income from its owners and investors. So a limited company operating in the Netherlands is incorporated in the UK if the limited company is registered in the national registrar of companies of the UK, the equivalent of the Dutch chamber of commerce.
